revision.text:
{{Infobox book <!-- |italic title = (see above) --> | name = The Giving Tree | image = The Giving Tree.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Cover depicting the tree giving away an apple | author = [[Shel Silverstein]] | series = | subject = | genre = [[Picture book|Children's picture book]] | publisher = [[Harper & Row]] | pub_date = October 7, 1964 | english_pub_date = | isbn = 978-0-06-025665-4 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} [[File:PikiWiki Israel 31909 The Giving Tree garden in Holon.jpg|250px|thumbnail|right|The Giving Tree Garden in Holon, Israel]]
'''''The Giving Tree''''' is a children's [[picture book]] written and illustrated by [[Shel Silverstein]]. First published in 1964 by [[Harper & Row]], it has become one of Silverstein's best known titles and has been translated into numerous languages.
This book has been described as "one of the most divisive books in children's literature." The controversy concerns whether the relationship between the main characters (a boy and a tree) should be interpreted as positive (i.e., the tree gives the boy [[Altruism|selfless love]]) or as negative (i.e., the boy and the tree have an abusive relationship).
==Background==
Silverstein had difficulty finding a publisher for ''The Giving Tree''.<ref name=NYT1973>{{cite news |title=About Alice, a Rabbit, a Tree... |author= Cole, William |newspaper=The New York Times |page=394|date=September 9, 1973}}</ref><ref name=NYT2011>{{cite news |title=The Children’s Authors Who Broke the Rules |author= Paul, Pamela|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/18/books/review/the-childrens-authors-who-broke-the-rules.html|newspaper=The New York Times |date=September 16, 2011 |accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> An editor at [[Simon & Schuster]] rejected the book's manuscript because he felt that it was "too sad" for children and "too simple" for adults.<ref name=NYT1973/><ref name=NYT2011/> [[Tomi Ungerer]] encouraged Silverstein to approach [[Ursula Nordstrom]], who was a publisher with Harper & Row.<ref name=NYT1973/>
An editor with Harper & Row stated that Silverstein had made the original illustrations "scratchy" like his cartoons for ''[[Playboy]]'', but that he later reworked the art in a "more pared-down and much sweeter style."<ref name=HornBook1999/> The final black-and-white drawings have been described as "unadorned… visual minimalism."<ref name=Spitz1999>{{cite book | last = Spitz | first = Ellen Handler | title = Inside Picture Books | publisher = Yale University Press | location = New Haven, CT | year = 1999 | isbn = 0300076029 | pages=142–144}}</ref> Harper & Row published a small first edition of the book, consisting of only 5,000–7,500 copies, in 1964.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Natov, Roni |author2=Geraldine DeLuca |lastauthoramp=yes |year= 1979 |title= Discovering Contemporary Classics: an Interview with Ursula Nordstrom|journal= [[The Lion and the Unicorn (journal)|The Lion and the Unicorn]] |volume= 3 |issue= 1 |pages =119–135 |url= http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/uni/summary/v003/3.1.natov01.html|access-date=May 18, 2013|doi= 10.1353/uni.0.0355 }}</ref>
==Plot summary== The book follows the lives of a female apple tree and a boy, who develop a relationship with one another. The tree is very "giving" and the boy evolves into a "taking" teenager, man, then elderly man. Despite the fact that the boy ages in the story, the tree addresses the boy as "Boy" his entire life.
In his childhood, the boy enjoys playing with the tree, climbing her trunk, swinging from her branches, carving "Me + T (Tree)" into the bark, and eating her apples. However, as the boy grows older, he spends less time with the tree and tends to visit her only when he wants material items at various stages of his life, or not coming to the tree alone (such as bringing a lady friend to the tree and carving "Me +Y.L." (her initials) into the tree. In an effort to make the boy happy at each of these stages, the tree gives him parts of herself, which he can transform into material items, such as money (from her apples), a house (from her branches), and a boat (from her trunk). With every stage of giving, "the Tree was happy".
In the final pages, both the tree and the boy feel the sting of their respective "giving" and "taking" nature. When only a stump remains for the tree (including the carving "Me + T"), she is not happy, at least at that moment. The boy does return as a tired elderly man to meet the tree once more. She tells him she is sad because she cannot provide him shade, apples, or any materials like in the past. He ignores this and states that all he wants is "a quiet place to sit and rest," which the tree, who is weak being just a stump, could provide. With this final stage of giving, "the Tree was happy".
==Reception==
Interest in the book increased by [[word of mouth]]; for example, in churches "it was hailed as a parable on the joys of giving."<ref name=NYT1973/> As of 2001, over 5 million copies of the book had been sold, placing it 14th on a list of hardcover "All-Time Bestselling Children's Books" from ''[[Publishers Weekly]].''<ref>{{cite journal |author= Roback, Diane, Jason Britton, and Debbie Hochman Turvey |date= December 17, 2001 |title= All-Time Bestselling Children's Books |journal= Publishers Weekly |volume= 248 |issue= 51 |url= http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20011217/28595-all-time-bestselling-children-s-books.html|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> By 2011, 8.5 million copies of the book had been sold.<ref name=NYT2011/>
In a 1999–2000 [[National Education Association]] online survey of children, among the "Kids' Top 100 Books," the book was 24th.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nea.org/grants/13110.htm |title= Kids' Top 100 Books |author= National Education Association |accessdate= May 18, 2013 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130201190330/http://www.nea.org/grants/13110.htm |archivedate= February 1, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Based on a 2007 online "Teachers' Top 100 Books for Children" poll by the National Education Association, the book came in third.<ref name=NEA2007>{{cite web |url= http://www.nea.org/grants/13154.htm/ |title= Teachers' Top 100 Books for Children |author= National Education Association |year= 2007|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> It was 85th of the "Top 100 Picture Books" of all time in a 2012 poll by ''[[School Library Journal]]''.<ref name=SLJPicture2012>{{cite web |url= http://blog.schoollibraryjournal.com/afuse8production/2012/07/06/top-100-picture-books-poll-results/ |title= Top 100 Picture Books Poll Results |author= Bird, Elizabeth | publisher=''[[School Library Journal]]'' "A Fuse #8 Production" blog|date= May 18, 2013|accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref> ''[[Scholastic Parent & Child]]'' magazine placed it #9 on its list of "100 Greatest Books for Kids" in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.scholastic.com/100books/pdf/Top_100_Childrens_Books_of_All_Time.pdf|title=Parent & Child 100 Greatest Books for Kids |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2012 |publisher= [[Scholastic Corporation]]|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> As of 2013, it ranked third on a [[Goodreads]] list of "Best Children's Books."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.goodreads.com/list/show/86.Best_Children_s_Books|title=Best Children's Books |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2008 |publisher= [[Goodreads]]|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref>
== Interpretations == {{weasel words|section|date=April 2015}} The book has generated various opinions on how to interpret the relationship between the tree and the boy. Some possible interpretations include:<ref name=Samuelsson1998>{{cite journal|last1=Pramling Samuelsson|first1=Ingrid |last2=Mauritzson|first2=Ulla|last3=Asplund Carlsson|first3=Maj|last4=Ueda|first4=Miyoko|title=A Mother and a Friend: Differences in Japanese and Swedish Mothers' Understanding of a Tale|journal=Childhood|volume=5|issue=4|year=1998|pages=493–506|issn=0907-5682|doi=10.1177/0907568298005004008}}</ref><ref name=Fraustino2008>{{cite book |last1=Fraustino |first1=Lisa Rowe |chapter=At the Core of The Giving Tree’s Signifying Apples |pages=284–306 | editor1-first=Annette M. |editor1-last=Magid | title = You Are What You Eat: Literary Probes into the Palate | publisher = Cambridge Scholars | location = Newcastle, UK | year = 2008 | isbn = 9781847184924 }}</ref>
===Religious interpretation=== Ursula Nordstrom attributed the book's success partially to "Protestant ministers and Sunday-school teachers", who believed that the tree represents "the Christian ideal of unconditional love."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/15/books/review/15MARCUSL.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|title='Runny Babbit': Hoppity Hip |first=Leonard S. |last=Marcus|date=May 15, 2005|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref>
===Environmental interpretation=== Some people believe that the tree represents [[Mother Nature]] and the boy represents humanity. The book has been used to teach children [[environmental ethics]].<ref>{{cite news |title=The Examined Life, Age 8 |author= Goodnough, Abby |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/18/education/edlife/18philosophy-t.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 16, 2010|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> An educational resource for children describes the book as an "allegory about the responsibilities a human being has for living organisms in the environment,"<ref>{{cite book | last = Fredericks | first = Anthony D. | title = The Librarian's Complete Guide to Involving Parents Through Children's Literature Grades K-6 | publisher = Libraries Unlimited | location = Englewood, CO | year = 1997 | isbn = 1563085380 |chapter= 26. The Giving Tree | page=28}}</ref> Lisa Rowe Fraustino states that “some curricula use the book as a what-not-to-do role model."<ref name=Fraustino2008/>
===Friendship interpretation=== One writer believes that the relationship between the boy and the tree is one of friendship. As such, the book teaches children "as your life becomes polluted with the trappings of the modern world — as you 'grow up' — your relationships tend to suffer if you let them fall to the wayside."<ref name=Belkin2010>{{cite web|url=http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/08/childrens-books-you-might-hate/|publisher=New York Times|title=Children’s Books You (Might) Hate|author=Belkin, Lisa|work="Motherlode: Adventures in Parenting" blog|date=September 8, 2010|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> Another writer's criticism of this interpretation is that the tree appears to be an adult when the boy is young, and cross-generational friendships are rare.<ref name=Belkin2010/>
===Parent–child interpretations=== A common interpretation of the book is that the tree and the boy have a parent–child relationship, as in a 1995 collection of essays about the book edited by [[Richard John Neuhaus]] in the journal ''[[First Things]]''.<ref name=FirstThings>{{cite journal|url=http://www.firstthings.com/article/2008/08/002-the-giving-tree-a-symposium-43|author=May, William F., Amy A. Kass, Marc Gellman, Midge Decter, Gilbert Meilaender, Mary Ann Glendon, William Werpehowski, Timothy Fuller, Leon R. Kass, Timothy P. Jackson, Jean Bethke Elshtain, Richard John Neuhaus|title=The Giving Tree: A Symposium|date=January 1995|publisher=The Institute on Religion and Public Life|journal=[[First Things]]|accessdate=May 18, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512035637/http://www.firstthings.com/article/2008/08/002-the-giving-tree-a-symposium-43|archivedate=May 12, 2013|df=}}</ref> Among the essayists, some were positive about the relationship; for example, [[Amy A. Kass]] wrote about the story that "it is wise and it is true about giving and about motherhood," and her husband [[Leon Kass|Leon R. Kass]] encourages people to read the book because the tree "is an emblem of the sacred memory of our own mother's love."<ref name=FirstThings/> Other essayists put forth negative views. [[Mary Ann Glendon]] wrote that the book is "a nursery tale for the 'me' generation, a primer of narcissism, a catechism of exploitation," and [[Jean Bethke Elshtain]] felt that the story ends with the tree and the boy "both wrecks."<ref name=FirstThings/>
A 1998 study using [[Phenomenography|phenomenographic]] methods found that Swedish children and mothers tended to interpret the book as dealing with friendship, while Japanese mothers tended to interpret the book as dealing with parent–child relationships.<ref name=Samuelsson1998/>
===Interpretation as satire=== Some authors believe that the book is not actually intended for children, but instead should be treated as a [[satire]] aimed at adults along the lines of ''[[A Modest Proposal]]'' by [[Jonathan Swift]].<ref name=JacksonDell>{{cite journal|author1=Jackson, Jacqueline |author2=Carol Dell |lastauthoramp=yes |year=1979 |title= The Other Giving Tree|journal=Language Arts |volume=56 |issue= 4|pages= 427–429|jstor=41404822 }}</ref><ref name=StrandburgLivo1986>{{cite journal|author1=Strandburg, Walter L. |author2=Norma J. Livo |lastauthoramp=yes |title=''The Giving Tree'' or There is a Sucker Born Every Minute|journal=Children's Literature in Education|volume=17|issue=1|year=1986|pages=17–24|doi=10.1007/BF01126946}}</ref>
== Criticism and controversy ==
Elizabeth Bird, writing for the ''School Library Journal'', described ''The Giving Tree'' as "one of the most divisive books in children's literature".<ref name=SLJ2012>{{cite web |url= http://blogs.slj.com/afuse8production/2012/05/18/top-100-picture-books-85-the-giving-tree-by-shel-silverstein/|title= Top 100 Picture Books #85: The Giving Tree by Shel Silverstein|author= Bird, Elizabeth | publisher=''[[School Library Journal]]'' "A Fuse #8 Production" blog|date= May 18, 2012|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> Criticism revolves about the depiction of the relationship between the boy and the tree.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Spitz, Ellen Handler|date=May–June 1999 |title= Classic children's book|journal=American Heritage |volume=50 |issue= 3|pages= 46|url=http://www.americanheritage.com/content/classic-children%E2%80%99s-book|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> {{quote |Totally self-effacing, the 'mother' treats her 'son' as if he were a perpetual infant, while he behaves toward her as if he were frozen in time as an importunate baby. This overrated picture book thus presents as a paradigm for young children a callously exploitative human relationship — both across genders and across generations. It perpetuates the myth of the selfless, all-giving mother who exists only to be used and the image of a male child who can offer no reciprocity, express no gratitude, feel no empathy — an insatiable creature who encounters no limits for his demands.}}
Critics of the book say that the boy never thanks the tree for its gifts.<ref>{{cite news |title=A Lesson from 'The Giving Tree' |author= Prosapio, Winter |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2006/0512/p18s03-hfes.html |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=May 12, 2006 |accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> In an interview with ''Horn Book Magazine'', Phyllis J. Fogelman, an editor with Harper & Row, said the book is "about a sadomasochistic relationship" and "elevates masochism to the level of a good",<ref name=HornBook1999>{{cite journal |author=Marcus, Leonard S. |date=March–April 1999 |title=An Interview with Phyllis J. Fogelman |journal=Horn Book Magazine |volume=75 |issue=2 |pages=148–164 |url=http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/~jtthomas/shelby.pdf |accessdate=May 18, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130108021228/http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/%7Ejtthomas/shelby.pdf# |archive-date=2013-01-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> which mirrors [[Mary Daly]]'s analysis in ''Gyn/Ecology: the Metaethics of Radical Feminism''.<ref>{{cite book | last = Daly | first = Mary | authorlink = Mary Daly| title = Gyn/Ecology: the Metaethics of Radical Feminism | publisher = Beacon Press | location = Boston | year = 1990 | isbn = 0807014133 | page = 90 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=_Vhe2AgQYckC&pg=PA90 | quote = Here is a model for masochism for female readers of all ages, and of sadism for boys of all ages...The saccharine sweet story of a little boy who 'loves' a tree—a young Apollo who crowns himself with her leaves—has 'healthier' appeal than overt S and M biblical tales of a dead godman crowned with thorns. }}</ref>
One college instructor discovered that the book caused both male and female [[Remedial education|remedial reading]] students to be angry because they felt that the boy exploited the tree.<ref name=Juchartz2004>{{cite journal |author= Juchartz, Larry R|date=December 2003 – January 2004 |title= Team Teaching with Dr. Seuss and Shel Silverstein in the College Basic Reading Classroom|journal= Journal of Adolescent & Adult Literacy |volume= 47|issue=4 |pages=336–341}}</ref> For teaching purposes, he paired the book with a short story by [[Andre Dubus]] entitled "The Fat Girl" because its plot can be described as ''The Giving Tree'' "in reverse."<ref name=Juchartz2004/>
=== Author's photograph === [[File:Shel Silverstein photograph on back cover of The Giving Tree.jpeg|thumb|Photograph of Silverstein that is used on the back cover of the book.]]
The photograph of Silverstein on the back cover of the book has attracted attention.<ref name=SLJ2012/><ref>{{cite news |title='SHELebration: A Tribute to Shel Silverstein' to Honor Writer Born in Chicago |author=Kogan, Rick |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2009-07-12/news/0907090678_1_shel-silverstein-saul-bellow-gwendolyn-brooks |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=July 12, 2009 |accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> One writer described the photograph as showing the author's "jagged menacing teeth" and "evil, glaring eyes."<ref>{{cite news |title=Children's books that creep me out: What was up with 'Natural Bear?' |author=Ruhalter, Eric |url=http://www.nj.com/parenting/eric_ruhalter/index.ssf/2010/01/childrens_books_sometimes_scar.html |newspaper=[[New Jersey On-Line]] |date=January 11, 2010 |accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> Another writer compared the photograph to the one on the back of ''[[Where the Sidewalk Ends (book)|Where the Sidewalk Ends]]'' in which Silverstein resembles "the Satanist [[Anton LaVey]]."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/~jtthomas/shelby.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160910154749/http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/~jtthomas/shelby.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-09-10|author=Thomas, Jr., Joseph|title=Reappraising Uncle Shelby||publisher=''[[The Horn Book Magazine]]''|date=2016-09-10|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> In the book ''[[Diary of a Wimpy Kid: The Last Straw]]'', the father threatens the protagonist with the photograph to make sure that he does not leave his room at night.<ref name=SLJ2012/><ref>{{cite book | author = Kinney, Jeff | title = Diary of a Wimpy Kid: the Last Straw | publisher = Amulet Books | location = New York | year = 2009 | isbn = 9780810970687|pages=17–19}}</ref>
==Cultural influences and adaptations==
===Other versions===
A short animated film of the book, produced in 1973, featured Silverstein's narration.<ref>{{cite AV media |people= Bosustow, Nick, and Shel Silverstein (Producers); Hayward, Charlie O. (Director and Animator); Silverstein, Shel (Original Story, Music, and Narration) |year= 1973|title=The Giving Tree |medium=VHS |publisher= SVE & Churchill Media|location=Chicago, IL |oclc= 48713769 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1TZCP6OqRlE |title= The Giving Tree: Based on the Book and Drawings by Shel Silverstein|year=1973 |publisher=Churchill Films|website=YouTube |accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref>
Silverstein also wrote a song of the same name, which was performed by [[Bobby Bare]] and his family on his album ''Singin' in the Kitchen'' (1974).<ref>{{cite AV media |people= Bobby Bare and the Family (Musicians); Silverstein, Shel (Principal Composer) |year= 1973|title=Singin' in the Kitchen|medium=LP |publisher=RCA Victor|location=New York|oclc= 6346534}}</ref>
Silverstein created an adult version of the story in a cartoon entitled "I Accept the Challenge."<ref name=":0" /> In the cartoon, a nude woman cuts off a nude man's arms and legs with scissors, then sits on his torso in a pose similar to the final drawing in ''The Giving Tree'' in which the old man sits on the stump.<ref name=":0" />
Jackson and Dell (1979) wrote an "alternative version" of the story for teaching purposes that was entitled "The Other Giving Tree."<ref name=JacksonDell/> It featured two trees next to each other and a boy growing up. One tree acted like the one in ''The Giving Tree'', ending up as a stump, while the other tree stopped at giving the boy apples, and does not give the boy its branches or trunk. At the end of the story, the stump was sad that the old man chose to sit under the shade of the other tree.<ref name=JacksonDell/>
===Cultural influences===
[[The Giving Tree Band]] took its name from the book.<ref>{{cite news |title=Giving Tree Band Takes Story to Heart |author= Markstrom, Serena |url= http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Giving+Tree+Band+takes+story+to+heart.-a0230805426|newspaper=[[The Register-Guard]] |date=June 18, 2010|accessdate=May 18, 2013}}</ref> Plain White T's EP ''[[Should've Gone to Bed]]'' has a song The Giving Tree, written by [[Tim Lopez]].
The 2010 short film ''[[I'm Here (film)|I'm Here]]'', written and directed by [[Spike Jonze]], is based on ''The Giving Tree''; the main character Sheldon is named after Shel Silverstein.<ref name="sundance">{{cite web |url=http://thefilmstage.com/news/sundance-review-spike-jonze-creates-unique-love-story-with-im-here/ |title= [Sundance Review] Spike Jonze Creates Unique Love Story With 'I'm Here'|author=Coates, Kristen |date=February 8, 2010 |website=The Film Stage |accessdate=May 18, 2013|quote='I was trying to take the influence of ''The Giving Tree'', but write about relationships,' says Jonze. 'I love Shel Silverstein. I just love him.'}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last1=Moriya|first1=Keiko|title=A Developmental and Crosscultural Study on the Interpersonal Cognition of Swedish and Japanese Children|journal=Scandinavian Journal of Educational Research|volume=33|issue=3|year=1989|pages=215–227|doi=10.1080/0031383890330304}} *{{cite journal|last1=Asplund Carlsson|first1=Maj |last2=Pramling|first2=Ingrid|last3=Wen|first3=Qiufeng|last4=Izumi|first4=Chise|title=Understanding a Tale in Sweden, Japan and China|journal=Early Child Development and Care|volume=120|issue=1|year=1996|pages=17–28|doi=10.1080/0300443961200102}} *{{cite book | editor = Costello, Peter R| title = Philosophy in Children's Literature | publisher = Lexington Books | location = Lanham, MD | year = 2012 | isbn = 9780739168233 | author =Miller, Ellen |chapter=15: The Giving Tree and Environmental Philosophy: Listening to Deep Ecology, Feminism and Trees |pages=251–266}} *{{cite book | editor = Costello, Peter R| title = Philosophy in Children's Literature | publisher = Lexington Books | location = Lanham, MD | year = 2012 | isbn = 9780739168233 | author =Radeva, Milena |chapter=16: The Giving Tree, Women, and the Great Society |pages=267–283}} *{{cite journal|last1=Hinson-Hasty|first1=Elizabeth|title=Revisiting Feminist Discussions of Sin and Genuine Humility|journal=Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion|volume=28|issue=1|year=2012|pages=108–114|doi=10.2979/jfemistudreli.28.1.108}}
==External links== {{Portal |Children's literature}} *{{cite news |title=Silverstein's 'The Giving Tree' Celebrates 40 Years in Print |author=Lindsey, Charley |url=http://staugustine.com/stories/061104/com_2373115.shtml |newspaper=Knight Ridder Newspapers |date= June 11, 2004}} *{{cite web |url=https://mises.org/daily/1652 |title=That Insufferable 'Giving Tree' |author=Westley, Christopher |date=October 21, 2004 |website=Mises Daily |publisher=[[Ludwig von Mises Institute]] }}
{{Shel Silverstein}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Piazza di Siena.jpg|thumb|Siena Square, inside the Villa Borghese gardens.]] [[Image:Rome-VillaBorghese-TempleEsculape.jpg|thumb|The 18th century "[[Temple of Aesculapius (Villa Borghese)|Temple of Aesculapius]]" built purely as a landscape feature, influenced by the lake at [[Stourhead]], [[Wiltshire]], [[England]].]]
'''Villa Borghese''' is a landscape [[garden]] in the naturalistic [[English landscape garden|English manner]] in [[Rome]], containing a number of buildings, museums (see [[Galleria Borghese]]) and attractions. It is the third largest public park in Rome (80 hectares or 197.7 acres) after the ones of the [[Villa Doria Pamphili]] and [[Villa Ada]]. The gardens were developed for the [[Galleria Borghese|Villa Borghese Pinciana]] ("Borghese villa on the [[Pincian Hill]]"), built by the architect Flaminio Ponzio, developing sketches by [[Scipione Borghese]], who used it as a ''villa suburbana'', a party villa, at the edge of Rome, and to house his art collection. The gardens as they are now were remade in the early nineteenth century.
==History== In 1605, Cardinal [[Scipione Borghese]], nephew of [[Pope Paul V]] and patron of [[Bernini]], began turning this former vineyard into the most extensive gardens built in Rome since Antiquity. The vineyard's site is identified with the [[gardens of Lucullus]], the most famous in the late Roman republic. In the 19th century much of the garden's former formality was remade as a landscape garden in the English taste (''illustration, right''). The Villa Borghese gardens were long informally open, but were bought by the commune of Rome and given to the public in 1903. The large landscape park in the English taste contains several villas. The [[Spanish Steps]] lead up to this park, and there is another entrance at the Porte del Popolo by [[Piazza del Popolo]]. The ''Pincio'' (the [[Pincian Hill]] of ancient Rome), in the south part of the park, offers one of the greatest views over Rome.
The Piazza di Siena, located in the villa, hosted the [[Equestrian at the 1960 Summer Olympics|equestrian]] [[dressage]], individual [[jumping]], and the jumping part of the [[eventing]] competition for the [[1960 Summer Olympics]]. A balustrade (dating from the early seventeenth century) from the gardens, was taken to England in the late 19th century, and installed in the grounds of [[Cliveden]] House, a mansion in [[Buckinghamshire]], in 1896. In 2004, a species of [[Papillifera papillaris|Italian snail]] was discovered, still living on the balustrade after more than 100 years in England.
==Villas in the gardens== *Today the [[Galleria Borghese]] is housed in the Villa Borghese itself. The garden '''Casino Borghese,''' built on a rise above the Villa by the architect [[Giovanni Vasanzio]], was set up by [[Pope Paul V|Camillo Borghese]] to contain sculptures by [[Bernini]] from the [[Borghese collection]], including his ''David'' and his ''Daphne'', and paintings by [[Titian]], [[Raphael]] and [[Caravaggio]]. *The [[Villa Giulia]] adjoining the Villa Borghese gardens was built in 1551 - 1555 as a summer residence for [[Pope Julius III]]; now it contains the Etruscan Museum (''Museo Etrusco'').
[[Image:Vista del jardín de la Villa Medici en Roma, por Diego Velázquez.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Painting by [[Diego Velázquez]]]] *The [[Villa Medici]] houses the [[French Academy in Rome]], and the ''Fortezzuola'' a Gothic garden structure that houses a collection memorializing the academic modern sculptor [[Pietro Canonica]]. In the 1650s, [[Diego Velázquez]] painted several depictions of this Villa's garden casino festively illuminated at night. Before electricity, such torchlit illuminations carried an excitement hard to conceive today. *Other villas scattered through the Villa Borghese gardens are remains of a [[International Exhibition of Art (1911)|world exposition]] in Rome in 1911. **The ''[[Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Moderna]]'' located in its grounds has a collection of 19th- and 20th-century paintings emphasizing Italian artists. **Architecturally the most notable of the 1911 exposition pavilions is the English pavilion designed by Sir [[Edwin Lutyens]] (who later designed [[New Delhi]]), now housing the [[British School at Rome]].
==Other points of interest== *The villa's gardens feature in one of [[Ottorino Respighi|Respighi]]'s ''[[Pini di Roma]]''. *The garden contains a replica of the Shakespeare's [[Globe Theatre]] built in 2003. *Beside the 1911 Exposition's villas, there is the Exposition's Zoo, recently redesigned, with minimal caging, as the [[Bioparco]], and the [[Museo Civico di Zoologia|Zoological Museum]] (''Museo di Zoologia''). *In 1873 a [[hydrochronometer]] on the 1867 design of Gian Battista Embriaco, O.P.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.casanatense.it/index.php/it/gli-editoriali/72-stampe-e-disegni/153-orologi.html?showall%3D1 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=March 20, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216190518/http://www.casanatense.it/index.php/it/gli-editoriali/72-stampe-e-disegni/153-orologi.html?showall=1 |archivedate=December 16, 2013 }} Accessed 20 March 2013: "È infatti del 1867 l'invenzione dell'idrocronometro, dovuta al padre domenicano Giovanni Battista Embriaco, che attese ai suoi studi di meccanica applicata all'orologeria nella solitudine del convento della Minerva."</ref> inventor and professor of the Roman [[Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas|College of St. Thomas]] was built in the gardens in emulation of the one at the [[Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas|College of St. Thomas]]. Another version stands in the gardens of the [[Pincian Hill]]. Embriaco had presented two prototypes of his invention at the [[International Exposition (1867)|Paris Universal Exposition]] in 1867 where it won prizes and great acclaim.<ref>https://www.comune.roma.it/PCR/resources/cms/documents/storia-idrocronometro.pdf Accessed 20 March 2013; "Storia del Progetto"</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:VillaBorgheseWaterClock.jpg|[[Water clock]] in Villa Borghese Image:Balvb.jpg|[[Tethered helium balloon]] Image:Alpinetroops(1).jpg|[[Alpini]] monument Image:Artemvb.jpg|Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Moderna File:Villa Borghese - monumento Ahmed Shawky 01215.JPG|[[Ahmed Shawqi]] monument Image:TeatroaVilla Borghese2.JPG|The Silvano Toti Globe Theatre </gallery>
==See also== * [[List of parks and gardens in Rome]]

page.title: Westward the Course of Empire Takes Its Way

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Emanuel Leutze - Westward the Course of Empire Takes Its Way - Capitol.jpg | painting_alignment = Oblique Left | image_size = 300px | title = Westward the Course of Empire Takes Its Way | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Emanuel Leutze]] | year = 1861 | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 20 | width_imperial = 30 | imperial_unit = ft | metric_unit = m | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | city = [[Washington, D.C.]] | museum = [[United States Capitol]] | coordinates = | owner = [[Architect of the Capitol]] }} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Emanuel Leutze - Westward the Course of Empire Takes Its Way - Smithsonian.jpg | painting_alignment = Oblique Left | image_size = 300px | title = Westward the Course of Empire Takes Its Way (study) | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Emanuel Leutze]] | year = 1861 | height_metric = 84.5 | width_metric = 110.1 | length_metric = | height_imperial = {{frac|33|1|4}} | width_imperial = {{frac|43|3|8}} | length_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Washington, D.C.]] | museum = [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] | coordinates = | owner = [[Smithsonian Institution]] }} '''''Westward the Course of Empire Takes Its Way''''' (also known as '''''Westward Ho''''') is a {{convert|20|x|30|ft|m|adj=on}} painted [[mural]] displayed behind the western staircase of the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] chamber in the [[United States Capitol|United States Capitol Building]]. The mural was painted by [[Emanuel Gottlieb Leutze]] in 1861 and symbolizes [[Manifest Destiny]], the belief that the United States was destined for Western exploration and expansion originating from the initial colonies along the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic seaboard]] to the [[Pacific ocean|Pacific Ocean]]. A study measuring {{convert|33+1/4|x|43+3/8|in|cm|1}} hangs in the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]].<ref> {{Cite web | title = Westward the Course of Empire Takes Its Way (mural study, U.S. Capitol) by Emanuel Gottlieb Leutze | work = Smithsonian American Art Museum and Renwick Gallery | accessdate = 2012-08-10 | url = http://americanart.si.edu/collections/search/artwork/?id=14569 }}</ref>
The darkness turning into light represents the greatness that was believed to lie in the future West.
== Content == Leutze combined pioneer men and women, mountain guides, wagons, and mules to suggest a divinely ordained pilgrimage to the Promised Land of the western frontier. Within the left half of the picture is a depiction of the entrance to the San Francisco Bay, the [[Golden Gate]], which is being pointed to by the pilgrim seated atop the rock in the foreground. Within the right hemisphere of the painting is a depiction of a valley, representing the Valley of Darkness and symbolic of the troubles faced by explorers. The imagery is familiar imperial iconography and is regarded as a symbol of [[American exceptionalism]] and the realization of [[Manifest Destiny]], ultimately leading to the evolution of the American Empire.
== Literary reference ==
The painting takes its inspiration from the closing lines of [[George Berkeley]]'s ''Verses on the Prospect of Planting Arts and Learning in America:
<poem> Westward the course of empire takes its way; The first four Acts already past, A fifth shall close the Drama with the day; Time's noblest offspring is the last. </poem>
== Influences == The imagery of the pilgrim gesturing on a high rock is very similar to the 5 cent [[postage stamp]], ''[[John C. Frémont|Fremont]] in the [[Rocky Mountains]]'' that was part of the 1898 [[Trans-Mississippi Issue]], and reprinted a century later.
A [[Currier and Ives]] print from 1868 uses the same title and theme for a very different print, showing a [[railroad]] crossing a new settlement as the train goes west.
A [[:File:'Westward The Course of Empire Takes Its Way' Laying Track 600 Miles West of St. Louis, Missouri, October 19, 1867.jpg|photographic print]] and a [https://www.kshs.org/km/items/view/153 stereograph] by [[Alexander Gardner (photographer)|Alexander Gardner]], both of an 1867 end-of-track frontier construction train, were titled "Westward The Course of Empire Takes Its Way".
== In popular culture ==
[[David Foster Wallace]] named one of his short stories "Westward the Course of Empire Takes Its Way" in his 1989 collection ''[[Girl with Curious Hair]]''.
Early revisions of the 1995 computer game ''[[Oregon Trail II]]'' depict the study version of this painting on the title screen.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Commonscat|Westward the Course of Empire Takes Its Way}} {{United States Capitol Complex}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Westward The Course Of Empire Takes Its Way}}
[[Category:Paintings by Emanuel Leutze]] [[Category:United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Masterpiece Museum]] [[Category:Paintings in the United States Capitol]] [[Category:1861 paintings]] [[Category:Horses in art]] [[Category:Cattle in art]] [[Category:Paintings of children]] [[Category:Death in art]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Flags in art]] [[Category:Water in art]] [[Category:Dogs in art]] [[Category:History paintings]]

[[File:Joaquín Murieta, The California Bandit.jpg|thumb|Picture, possibly by [[Charles Nahl]], of "[[Joaquin Murieta|Joaquín Murieta]], The California Bandit", from the rarest book of the Zamorano 80, ''The Life and Adventures of Joaquín Murieta'', 1854]] The '''Zamorano Eighty''' is a list of books intended to represent the most significant early volumes published on the [[History of California|history]] of [[California]]. It was compiled in 1945 by members of the Zamorano Club, a [[Los Angeles]]-based group of [[bibliophile]]s. Collecting [[first edition]]s of every volume on the list has become the goal of a number of book collectors, though to date only four people have completed the task.<ref name="volkmann">{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Dan-Volkmann-collector-of-rare-books-dies-3162597.php | title=Dan Volkmann, collector of rare books, dies | publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]] | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date=May 7, 2009 | accessdate=May 30, 2013 | author=Tucker, Jill}}</ref>
The Zamorano Club was founded in 1928 and named for [[Agustín Vicente Zamorano]], the first [[Printer (publisher)|printer]] in California.<ref name="zhistory">{{cite web | url=http://www.zamoranoclubla.org/history/ | title=History of the Zamorano Club | publisher=The Zamorano Club | accessdate=June 3, 2013 | author=Nunis, Doyce B., Jr.}}</ref><ref name="Madness">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Z-KL2voBoUC | title=A Gentle Madness: Bibliophiles, Bibliomanes, and the Eternal Passion for Books | publisher=Henry Holt and Company | author=Basbanes, Nicholas A. | authorlink=Nicholas A. Basbanes | date=March 15, 1999 | pages=492–6 | isbn=978-0-8050-6176-5}}</ref><ref name="Clifford ">{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-09-18/local/me-3445_1_zamorano-club | title=An Exclusive Club of Many Chapters | publisher=[[Tribune Company]] | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=September 18, 1988 | accessdate=June 4, 2013 | author=Soble, Ronald L.}}</ref> A series of committees of Club members, including former [[American Smelting and Refining Company]] executive [[Henry Raup Wagner]] and bibliographer Robert Cowan, assembled a list of a hundred books, eventually whittled down to eighty. During this process, Cowan died, and his ''Bibliography of the History of California and the Pacific West'' was added to the list as a tribute.<ref name="z80">{{cite web | url=http://www.zamoranoclubla.org/zam80/ | title=The Zamorano 80 | publisher=The Zamorano Club | accessdate=June 4, 2013}}</ref>
The list contains significant works by a number of well-known authors like [[Mark Twain]], [[John Muir]], [[Bret Harte]], and [[Robert Louis Stevenson]], as well as obscure texts concerning geographical exploration and legal matters. Some of the works exist in very few, highly sought after copies, while others were quite common and not particularly valuable, until interest in the list caused their prices to rise.<ref name="Water2010">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pIuC3A4_v_UC | title=The Zamorano 80 Revisited: A Collector's Update of a Classic Work | publisher=Xlibris Corporation | date=April 16, 2010 | accessdate=May 30, 2013 | author=Gordon J. Water | page=xi | isbn=978-1-4628-1868-6}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=January 2018}}</ref> Book dealers often refer to items for sale using their "Zamorano number" or have special sections dedicated to items on the list.
Thomas Streeter was the first collector to assemble a complete collection of first editions of every item on the list. His collection was auctioned between 1966 and 1969.<ref name="z80"/> Businessman Frederick William Beinecke was the second. Retired investment counselor Henry H. Clifford completed his collection in 1988 and his collection was auctioned in 1995. The fourth was architect Daniel Volkmann, who completed his collection in 1994, and it was auctioned in 2003.<ref name=volkmann /><ref name="z80"/><ref name=Clifford /> Many other collectors have pursued this goal, including notorious [[bibliomane]] and book thief [[Stephen Blumberg]].<ref name=Madness />
Only one institution, the [[Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library]] at [[Yale University]], possesses a complete collection of the Zamorano 80, donated by Frederick W. Beinecke. Both the [[Bancroft Library]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] and the [[Huntington Library]] in [[San Marino, California]] possess all but one of the volumes.<ref name="Sloan">{{cite web | url=http://www.dsloan.com/Auctions/A12/DSIntro.htm | title=The Zamorano 80 | publisher=Dorothy Sloan Books | accessdate=May 30, 2013 | author=Sloan, Dorothy}}</ref>
The rarest book on the list is number 64, the [[dime novel]] ''[[The Life and Adventures of Joaquín Murieta]]'' by [[John Rollin Ridge]] writing as "Yellow Bird". Only two first-edition copies are known to exist, each used twice to complete the list.<ref name=sloanJM /> It may be on the list only because Wagner owned a copy, which he sold to Streeter. When Streeter's collection was being periodically auctioned, the auction of this copy was moved up over a year so the elderly Beinecke would be able to complete his Zamorano collection. This copy is now in the Beinecke Library with the rest of Beinecke's Zamorano books.<ref name="sloanJM">{{cite web | url=http://www.dsloan.com/Auctions/A12/64WebA12.htm | title=Auction 12: The Zamorano 80 Collection of Daniel G. Volkmann Jr. Lots 64 & 64A Item 64. The exceedingly rare Life and Adventures of Joaquín Murieta | publisher=Dorothy Sloan Books | accessdate=June 4, 2013}}</ref><ref name="AE">{{cite journal | url=http://www.americanaexchange.com/articles/27 | title=The Elusive Zamorano 80 Captured Again: The Volkmann Zamorano 80 under the Hammer in February | author=Wilkie, Everett | journal=Americana Exchange Monthly | accessdate=June 4, 2013}}</ref> Clifford purchased the second copy from a collector in Maine, which in turn was purchased by Volkmann at the auction of Clifford's collection.<ref name=Water2010 /><ref name=Clifford /> The book has been described with terms like "[[Holy Grail]]"<ref name=volkmann /> and "[[wikt:Special:Search/rara avis|rara avis]]"<ref name="sloanJM"/> and is highly desired by collectors. Blumberg wanted it so much he and his accomplices planned and researched a potential burglary of Clifford's house when that collector owned the book.<ref name=Madness />
==The Zamorano Eighty==
The works on the list are numbered in alphabetical order by author (or title, in the case of numbers 14, 35, and 62) and were not intended to be any sort of ranking of literary or financial value.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! # !! Author !! Title !! Year !!class="unsortable"| Cover or title page |- | 1|| {{sortname|Gertrude|Atherton}} || ''The Splendid Idle Forties: Stories of Old California'' || 1902 || [[File:Gertrude Atherton The Splendid Idle Forties 1902.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 2|| {{sortname|Mary|Austin}} || ''[[The Land of Little Rain]]'' || 1903 || [[File:The Land of Little Rain title page.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 3|| {{sortname|Hubert Howe|Bancroft}} || ''Works'', 39 volumes || 1882–90 || [[File:Hubert Howe Bancroft Works Volume 21.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 4|| {{sortname|Frederick William|Beechey}} || ''Narrative of a Voyage to the Pacific and Beering's Strait, to Co-Operate with the Polar Expeditions: Performed in His Majesty's Ship [[HMS Blossom (1806)|Blossom]], under the Command of Captain F. W. Beechey'', 2 volumes || 1831 || [[File:Frederick William Beechey Narrative of a Voyage to the Pacific.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 5|| {{sortname|Horace|Bell}} || ''Reminiscences of a Ranger: Early Times in Southern California'' || 1881 || [[File:Reminiscences of a Ranger - Horace Bell.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 6|| {{sortname|Anthony J.|Bledsoe}} || ''Indian Wars of the Northwest: A California Sketch'' || 1885 || [[File:Indian wars of the Northwest.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 7|| {{sortname|Herbert Eugene|Bolton}} || ''Anza's California Expeditions'', 5 volumes|| 1930 || <center>–</center> |- | 8|| {{sortname|John David|Borthwick}} || ''Three Years in California'' || 1857 || [[File:John David Borthwick Three years in California.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 9|| {{sortname|William Henry|Brewer}} || ''Up and Down California in 1860–1864: The Journal of William H. Brewer'' || 1930 || <center>–</center> |- | 10|| {{sortname|John Henry|Brown|nolink=1}} || ''Reminiscences and Incidents of The Early Days of San Francisco'' || 1886 || [[File:The Early Days of San Francisco.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 11 || {{sortname|John Ross|Browne}} || ''Report of the Debates in the Convention of California, on the Formation of the State Constitution, in September and October, 1849 || 1850 || [[File:Report of the debates in the Convention of California.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 12 || {{sortname|Edwin|Bryant||dab=alcalde}} || ''What I Saw in California: Being the Journal of a Tour, by the Emigrant Route and South Pass of the Rocky Mountains, across the Continent of North America, the Great Desert Basin, and through California, in the Years 1846, 1847'' || 1849 || [[File:Edwin Bryant What I Saw in California.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 13 || {{sortname|Peter Hardeman|Burnett}} || ''Recollections and Opinions of an Old Pioneer'' || 1880 || [[File:Recollections and opinions of an old pioneer.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 14 || various authors || ''California and New Mexico: Message from the President of the United States, Transmitting Information in Answer to a Resolution of the House of the 31st of December, 1849, on the Subject of California and New Mexico'' || 1850 || [[File:Message from the President of the United States on the subject of California and New Mexico.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 15|| {{sortname|Carlos Antonio|Carrillo}} || ''Exposicion Dirigida a la Camara de Diputados Del Congreso de la Union'' || 1831 || [[File:Exposición dirigida á la Cámara de Diputados del Congreso de la Unión.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 16 || {{sortname|James H.|Carson}} || ''Early Recollections of the Mines and a Description of the Great Tulare Valley'' || 1852 || [[File:Early recollections of the mines.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 17 || {{sortname|Samuel|Clemens}} || ''[[The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County]], and Other Sketches'' || 1867 || [[File:TheCelebratedJumpingFrog.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 18 || {{sortname|Samuel|Clemens}} || ''[[Roughing It]]'' || 1872 || [[File:Twain RoughingIt.jpg|100px|alt=book cover]] |- | 19 || {{sortname|James|Clyman}} || ''James Clyman, American Frontiersman, 1792–1881: The adventures of a trapper and covered wagon emigrant as told in his
